cards.title: Qubit
cards.text: Quantum Bit. The basic unit of quantum information. Unlike a classical bit (0 or 1), a qubit can exist in a superposition of both states simultaneously.

cards.title: Superposition
cards.text: The "AND" State. A quantum state where a particle exists in all possible configurations at once. Collapses to a single state only when measured.

cards.title: Entanglement
cards.text: Spooky Action at a Distance. A phenomenon where two particles become linked. Changing the state of one instantly affects the other, regardless of distance.

cards.title: Decoherence
cards.text: The Noise Problem. When a quantum system interacts with its environment (heat, light) and loses its quantum state, reverting to classical physics. The biggest challenge in building quantum computers.

cards.title: Quantum Supremacy
cards.text: The Tipping Point. The moment a quantum computer solves a problem that is practically impossible for even the most powerful classical supercomputer to solve.

cards.title: Interference
cards.text: Wave Mechanics. Quantum states can interfere like waves. Algorithms use constructive interference to amplify correct answers and destructive interference to cancel out wrong ones.
